newsitem.title: USA: Rains slows Kansas wheat harvest, ratings improve.
newsitem.headline: Rains slows Kansas wheat harvest, ratings improve.

text.p: Scattered showers slowed the Kansas wheat harvest in the week to Sunday, the state's agricultural statistics service said in its weekly crop update.
The harvest was 15 percent complete, down from last year's 39 percent and a five-year average of 38 percent.
"Most of the harvest activity is located in the southern one-third of the state," the report said.
The crop was rated 75 percent good or excellent, up from 68 percent a week earlier. The crop was 55 percent ripe, down from a five-year average of 72 percent.
Sorghum was 98 percent planted, ahead of the average of 92 percent and was rated 85 percent good or excellent.
Soybeans were 99 percent planted, up from a normal 90 percent, and rated 84 percent good or excellent. "Acreage remaining to be planted is double crop following wheat," the report noted.
Pasture condition was rated 80 percent good or excellent, unchanged from a week earlier.
Topsoil moisture was 18 percent surplus, 66 percent adequate, 15 percent short and one percent very short.
